title: 'Gentle giant' boxer left man with brain injuries after single punch attack outside pub
text:
News 'Gentle giant' boxer left man with brain injuries after single punch attack outside pub ‘Gentle giant’ Alex Bloomer, who left the victim with three bleeds on the brain and two bruises, was spared jail after admitting GBH Share Get daily updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email 
A boxer left a pubgoer with brain injuries after trouble flared outside a Didsbury pub. 
Amateur super heavyweight Alex Bloomer, of Blackfriars Road, Salford, turned on his heels and felled his 28-year-old victim with a single punch. 
The actions of IT recruitment consultant Bloomer, 27, left the victim with three bleeds on the brain and two bruises. 
But the 27-year-old, who trained to fight at Donnington Boxing Club in Shropshire, was spared jail after admitting GBH. 
The court heard he was normally a ‘gentle giant’ - and the judge concluded he was ‘not a man who the public need to be protected from’. 
Manchester Crown Court heard that in the early hours of June 25 the 28-year-old victim and his friend were talking about ‘Brexit’ with two women outside the Metropolitan pub in West Didsbury. Read More Driver accused of killing two young cousins in crash admits failing to stop - but denies dangerous driving 
At some point the men came to believe that Bloomer had deliberately spat at one of them, but he walked past them and said nothing when they complained. 
The 28-year-old victim, who admits he was shouting abuse, and two of his friends then followed Bloomer down Lapwing Lane - before Bloomer turned around and knocked the victim out with a punch to his right jaw. 
An ambulance was called and the victim was taken by ambulance to Wythenshawe Hospital. There, his head was bandaged but he left before a brain scan. Hours later he was forced to return to hospital because he was suffering from headaches and vomiting. 
A brain scan then revealed a ‘severe head injury’ - prosecutor Tim Greenald said - comprising a three separate bleeds on the brain and two bruises. The victim, who also suffered two fractured front teeth, was a hospital in-patient for ten days. 
Mr Greenald said the attack had a physical and emotional impact on the victim. 
“He refers to ongoing affects on his memory and talks about some nights where he loses sleep due to thinking about the attack and the investigation”, the prosecutor added. Read More Teacher jailed after hurling drunken racist abuse - and MOCKING a brain-damaged passenger on a plane 
Adrian Farrow, defending, said Bloomer was a man of ‘positive good character’, adding: “He finds himself facing the very real prospect of custody because of this wholly uncharacteristic moment of loss of self control. He’s not someone who goes out looking for trouble or responds inappropriately to stressful situations, either socially or in his work - the phrase gentle giant is used by those who know him. 
"He’s a peacekeeper, likely to defuse situations rather than inflame them.” 
Handing him an eight month sentence suspended for a year, and an order to compensate the victim £2,000, Judge Patrick Field QC told Bloomer: “It’s without doubt that you are a young man of considerable potential - you are highly thought thought by your peers. It was but a single blow, a blow undoubtedly delivered with the skill of a boxer, thus a calculated blow and one that was part of a wholly disproportionate display of belligerence. 
“That blow was sufficiently hard to break the victim’s front teeth and knock him to the ground, his head striking the ground with sufficient force to render him unconscious. Let’s be frank - this is the sort of blow that in similar circumstances could have caused a man’s death.” Like us on Facebook
